name: Hard Global Philosophy Quiz / Test | Humanities | 10 Questions

questions.text: Who was the first Greek philosopher responsible for eradicating the notion of 'mythic causes' for natural phenomena, and established the guiding principles for scientific investigation?
This Greek thinker established that the origin of the Universe was from a boundless, indefinite 'arche'...perhaps tantamount with the eternal yet evolving God.
Which thinker first formulated the usage of the Trinity, in the religious sense?
questions.explanation:
Tertullian.

	Tertullian formulated God as tres personae, una substantia. Pope Damascus approved this usage and thus incorporated it into the scriptures.

questions.text: He was the most influential Renaissance philosopher, translating for the first time the Dialogues of Plato and Plotinus into Latin. He also wrote a seminal commentary on Plato....'Theology of Plato'- who was he?
He was the last of the Cappodicians and perhaps the first Christian philosopher.
questions.explanation:
St. Gregory of Nyssa

	Epektasis, the continual perfection of the soul was the key to bridging some of the Platonic ideas with Christin theology. Epektasis conceptualizes the need for the soul to continually evolve into a higher level...an idea which is similarly found in Buddhism.

questions.text: Which of the following Chinese thinkers was a direct descendant intellectually of the great central Asian Buddhist teacher Kumarajiva?
questions.explanation:
Seng-chao.

	Kumarajiva (344-413 AD)..emphasized sunyata (nothingness) and believed in the teachings of the Lotus Sutras. Nicheren and Jetsun Milarepa are also important figures in Asia with the same philosophy.

questions.text: What famous German mystic wrote these words: 'When God looks at the soul he laughs, when the soul looks at God, the soul laughs back at God'?
Who was the Jewish philosopher and doctor of the Middle Ages, who wrote the 'Guide of the Perplexed' in order to help Jewish believers reach a deeper insight into esoteric truths?
An interesting savant from the Ammonius school, who was first to refute quite successfully the Aristotelian theory of the eternity of the universe?

Coeval philosopher during the time of St. Augustine, who developed a dogma concerning the denial of the 'Original Sin', and determined that humans could perfect themselves or corrupt themselves according to individual lifestyles?
questions.explanation:
Pelagius.

	He originated the idea of the Inner light within us,...ideas now used similarly by the Quakers.
